b"b' Automatic syntax highlighting appropriate to shebang'"

b'b\' ### Demo Below indented block:   #!/ ruby  require "awesomeness"  would be transformed to: #!/ rubyrequire "awesomeness"  Similarly fenced block  would be transformed to: #!/set +awesomeness ### Additional remark Fenced blocks w/ syntax  highlighting appropriate to language tag are nice
column11: but IMO they don\\\'t look as good as indented blocks for raw reading
column12: i.e. when they are unformatted. It\\\'s important for README and other files distributed w/o any preprocessing. Such automatic syntax highlighting would help a lot here.\''

column10: b"b' Closing parenthesis in a link'"
b'b" Hi
column11: I\'d like to make a link with a closing parenthesis in it
column12: but escaping with a backslash doesn\'t seem to be enough. The typical use case is Wikipedia pages (disambiguation). For example
column13: I\'m expecting to generate this output:  "'

column10: b'b" Hey Bruno
column11: sorry for the delay on fixing this. I\'ve just rolled out full escaping support for all URIs in Redcarpet. Links like [Pogo]url  should be working now. As you can see
column12: now we also URI-encode strange characters in the URL
column13: like the parenthesis on that previous link. This should make everything safer & smoother. Thanks for reporting! Shout if you find more issues."'

column10: b'b" Hi
column11: don\'t be sorry. It\'s very nice to have a great markdown lib and someone that fixes our bugs :-)"'

column10: b"b' Hum
column11: seems like the URI-encoding does not like accents. For example
column12: with  There are some that have nothing to do there.'"

column10: b"b' Grumpf. Does  also have something against my characters? My example was:  '"
b'b" I\'ve proposed a fix on url "'
b'b" Hey Bruno
column11: thanks for the fix. However
column12: I\'ve been reading the RFC standard for URI percent encoding
column13: and turns out we\'re doing it improperly. You\'re not supposed to encode random characters
column14: only reserved characters (like or  ) if they are not acting in their reserved behavior. Relevant snippets:So
column16: we were doing the exact opposite. I\'ve fixed this by dropping support for URI encoding altogether
column17: because we can expect that the producer of the URI has already encoded it properly -it\'s ambiguous to try to guess which reserved characters are actually reserved and which are not. I\'ll be rolling this out soon. Sorry for the wasted effort!"'

column10: b"b' Oh
column11: and regarding the Unicode characters -yes
column12: chokes on them. We already have an issue open about that
column13: working on it. :) Rolling out the escaping fix now...'"

column13: but ATM it\'s turned on at GitHub to ease the transition from Discount.   Thanks for reporting!"'

column10: b'b" Np with the questions. My job. By default

column10: b'b" Hey man
column11: here\'s an old comment on the Upskirt source which explains the issue with backtick conflicts
column12: I hope it makes sense to you: Regarding Markdown via email
column13: sorry about the confusion. There\'s no security vulnerability that we know of
column14: we\'re not supporting that feature because of usability issues: we\'ve found out in the past that enabling MD in email is a clusterfuck of failure (we tried it on Tender) because people just expect their emails to be in plaintext (e.g. they just copy and paste code into the email)
column15: and the end result is always crazy formatting. If you add to that the fact that you get no Markdown preview once you reply to the email
column16: you end up with a **lot** of broken formatting on the website. That\'s why we just show plaintext from email replies at GitHub -no formatting whatsoever. Email is and should always be plaintext. Lastly
column17: the autoimage feature was already on my TODO list... It\'ll sure come in handy
column18: but with so many corner cases I want to make sure the implementation is solid. Cheers man
column19: hope that was helpful. PS: nice website there
column20: though I\'m more into dubstep than hiphop these days. ;) If you are indeed considering to switch to Redcarpet there
column21: feel free to open as many issues as you require to make the transition as smooth as possible. I\'m here to help."'

column10: b'b" I\'m frustrated that issue #175 was closed so flippantly. Several users complained that does not output newlines and the response is that the output is plaintext and therefore has no break tags. That is entirely irrelevant. The goal is to strip the markdown to plaintext
column11: with carriage . The issue was open for 5 months and dismissed in 5 seconds. You can argue that the behaviour is as intended
column12: but it does not invalidate the desired solution."'

column10: b"b' I think this behavior is not correct. Plaintext is indeed plaintext
column11: which means that instead of break tags it has newline characters. The plaintext renderer should try to conserve the original newlines and insert new ones wherever line breaks originally was.'"

b'b" Hi @jcheatham
column11: Yep I think it\'s a Nokogiri update or something like this as the helper relies on it. As for the second change
column12: this is pretty strange as the conformance suite doesn\'t pass on my computer but it does on Travis. I need to investigate a bit before merging this unfortunately. I will also give some feedback a bit later. Thanks a ton anyway! :heart:"'

column10: b'b" No problem
column11: @robin850.  Funnily enough this also failed for me at first
column12: but then worked after I got frustrated and did a completely clean build... The problem is primarily the inconsistency of passing along a single backslash when encountering an unknown escape sequence (e.g. the \\\\p in the test).  We could strip the backslash from an unknown sequence or drop the entire sequence altogether... but this seemed like more likely to lead to user confusion
column13: while I couldn\'t find a strong case for requiring an escape-sequence here. Happy for any feedback

column10: b'b" Ok
column11: I\'m sorry @jcheatham but I will close this one. Actually we can\'t remove the back-slash from the list of escaped chars and the markdown you\'ve can\'t generate the output you\'re expecting. The [original Markdown implementation]url  and Redcarpet both return which seems correct. This is also the behavior of the command: Moreover
column12: reading the file from Ruby and inspecting it returns a string with 16 backslashes for the first line (which seems pretty big but logical). Feel free to comment if I\'m wrong and I will reopen ; thanks for your work on Redcarpet anyway
column13: we really appreciate ! :heart:"'

column10: b'b\' Hi @robin850
column11: Oh
column12: I\\\'m definitely familiar with the madness associated with backslash escape sequence expansion + the shell... I just think in this case it\\\'s more a matter of expectation & UX.  As a user entering text into a field
column13: even though they might be markdown-savvy they typically aren\\\'t expecting to have to deal with using 3 or 4 slashes in order to get 2 when a single slash shows up just fine (when it\\\'s not part of an escape sequence) as it\\\'s inconsistent.  They can (hopefully) click "Preview" on whatever form they\\\'re using and get feedback and keep adding slashes as necessary
column14: but it\\\'s kind of a poor justification to tell them the reason it has to work that way is "well
column15: it\\\'s because a bunch of other tools also exhibit this behavior so we\\\'ll just perpetuate it".  If the escape sequence is necessary for some _other_ functionality I\\\'m totally oblivious to I\\\'d love to hear it of course
column16: otherwise I think we might just have to fork... hmmm... or what about if this was done through a run-time or compile-time flag to enable the behavior on demand? Thanks for the consideration
column17: and I hope you\\\'ll give this issue just a bit more from a poor confused user\\\'s perspective :)\''

b"b' Optional Reference-Style Link Space'"
b"b' Markdown allows a space between the square brackets of a reference style link
column11: but that behavior creates ambiguity and [interference with extensions like task lists]url  ### Reference  ### Ambiguity   Red Carpet renders this as:   but
column12: other markdown engines (like GitHub Flavored Markdown) have disabled the optional space and render it as:    ### Interference   Extensions like task lists work by filtering list items looking for lines starting with
column13: but Red Carpet will have already transformed them into links:   If Red Carpet had a way to disable the optional space the ambiguity would be resolved.    ### Proposal  Add an option named that defaults to true
column14: that determines if the optional space is recognized.'"

column10: b"b'  url Wrapping this in a conditional should achieve the desired behavior. '"
b"b' I am closing this since the space is explicitly included in the markdown spec. It should be possible to fix the link after redcarpet gets done mangling it.'"
b"b' @robin850 Reopening per url  This causes problems with normal markdown usage and popular extensions like task lists. Would you consider the option to disable the space inside links
column11: or even disable by default it in a future major version?'"

column10: b"b' @robin850 The solution from url  does not help with task lists.   takes priority over resulting in: '"
b'b" Hi @deckar01 !  Yes unfortunately ! I don\'t know what we can do here ; I would love to try to avoid as much as possible the option path
column11: there are still enough options to enable. GitHub Flavored Markdown is actually a super set of CommonMark and the latter explicitly forbids spaces: This is why this is not a problem in their case. I will try to think about a possible solution but I guess your best option here for now is to escape the checkbox brackets with a slash ; sorry about that. \\xf0\\x9f\\x98\\x95"'

column10: b"b' Thanks for your insight.'"

column10: b'b" So the docs are just wrong then. It doesn\'t work like that at all.  Here\'s how I fixed it for people looking for this in the future  "'

column12: the README file properly makes the distinction between Markdown and render options but I agree that we can do a better job since most people won\'t carefully read the whole file but just trying to roughly skim it.  Thanks for spotting this anyway !"'
